definition: In biology, a **cell** is the <u>basic unit of life</u> - a <u>membrane-bound structure containing the fundamental molecules and organelles needed for life</u>. Some organisms consist of a single cell (e.g. bacteria or yeast), while others are multicellular with specialized cell types that work together in tissues and organs. Cells are categorized as **prokaryotic (lacking a nucleus)** or **eukaryotic (having a nucleus and organelles)**.
tips: **Cell theory:** All living organisms are made of one or more cells, the cell is the <u>basic unit of life</u>, and <u>new cells arise from existing cells</u>.

Prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea) are <u>unicellular, lack a nucleus, and have 70S ribosomes</u>; Eukaryotes (protists, fungi, plants, animals) have a <u>nucleus, membrane-bound organelles, and 80S cytoplasmic ribosomes</u>.

Some cells (like bacteria) are <u>independent organisms</u>, whereas in multicellular organisms, cells <u>differentiate and cooperate</u> (e.g., muscle cells vs nerve cells) to maintain the whole organism.
exam_appearance: Cell theory questions - e.g., -What are the tenets of cell theory-- Expect: <u>(1) all living things composed of cells, (2) cell is basic unit of life, (3) cells come from preexisting cells</u>.
Prokaryote vs. eukaryote ID - If a described cell has <u>no nucleus and a small size (~1-5 -m)</u>, it-s prokaryotic. If it has a <u>nucleus and organelles (and ~10-100 -m size)</u>, it-s eukaryotic.
Vital distinction - Viruses are often contrasted with cells: remember <u>viruses are not cells (acellular)</u>, reinforcing that cells are the <u>smallest living units</u> (viruses aren-t -alive-).
